qas.question: What high sounding title was adopted by anyone who could get away with it?
How did most Georgian design styles disseminate?

answers.text: pattern books and inexpensive suites of engravings

qas.question: How did styles disseminate before Georgian architecture?
Which American author received editions of Georgian architecture?
What years were William Halfpenny active?
What high sounding title was reserved for professionals before the mid-century??
After what time did anybody you could get away with using the title architect do so?
What style of architecture disseminated through the new professional architecture?
From what century on the architect's and craftsmen stop learning the Georgian style?

context: The period saw the growth of a distinct and trained architectural profession; before the <b6_0>mid-century<b6_0/> "the high-sounding title, '<a0_0><b5_0>architect<b5_0/><a0_0/>' was adopted by anyone who could get away with it". But most <b7_0>buildings<b7_0/> were still designed by builders and landlords together, and the wide spread of Georgian architecture, and the <b8_0>Georgian styles<b8_0/> of design more generally, came from dissemination through <a1_0>pattern books and inexpensive suites of engravings<a1_0/>. This contrasted with earlier styles, which were primarily disseminated among craftsmen through the direct experience of <a2_0>the apprenticeship system<a2_0/>. Authors such as the prolific <a3_0>William Halfpenny<a3_0/> (active <a4_0>1723–1755<a4_0/>) received editions in America as well as Britain. From the <b9_0>mid-18th century<b9_0/>, Georgian styles were assimilated into an architectural vernacular that became part and parcel of the training of every architect, designer, builder, carpenter, mason and plasterer, from Edinburgh to Maryland.
